Pletar, as years go by, file sizes go up. 10 years ago an avengers scan was 4mb and now it's 40. but 10 years ago my laptop had a 12 gig hard drive, now it's 120. i know it's problematic, and there are several scanners that keep their file sizes down -- conserving hard drive space and transfer time without a noticeable sacrifice in quality. however those aren't usually the releases you'll find here, and i think that's because the scanners who release a book on wednesday morning usually are more interested in getting out the .cbr as quickly as possible (and don't get me wrong, they do amazing work).

as far as fitting your screen, use CDisplayEx and the option fit to screen or the fit landscape menu.

and one more thing, not trying to be an asshole but i always say if you don't like the files, go spend $3-$4 and buy a printed copy. printed copies use zero bandwidth and zero drive space!

The increase in file sizes are because of the increase in resolution of the files released digitally - from 1280px to 1920px (page widths). This probably happened because tablets are increasing in resolution.

This is a good thing, as storage space is cheap...and the increased resolution will provide a much better experience in the future on higher resolution devices :D
